div1.p: Reynolds learns that John R. Taylor had no direct connection to the yellow fever experiments and states that he should not be included in the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Memorandum from Charles R. Reynolds to the Adjutant General, June 19, 1937 [Enclosed in KAFA0300]
div1.p:
Subject: Addition of name of John R. Taylor to Roll of Honor,
Participants in Yellow Fever Investigations in Cuba.

1. Inclosed is S. 2623, a bill introduced June 7, 1937, and
referred to the Committee on Military Affairs of the Senate, which
would include the name of John R. Taylor with those recognized for
their high public service in association with Major Walter Reed dur-
ing his experiments with yellow fever in Cuba.

2. I have no personal information regarding the merits of
this case as I was not in Cuba and in no way associated with Walter
Reed and his coworkers. However, I have received, personally and
otherwise, a number of protests from those having positive and direct
information regarding the facts in the case, from which I am lead to
believe that John R. Taylor suffered an attack of yellow fever in
Cuba which was in no wise connected with Reed's experiments nor was
Taylor involved or employed in the work done by Walter Reed. I am
further told that Taylor's attack of yellow fever did nothing to
advance medical knowledge regarding this disease or bring about, directly
or indirectly, any of the discoveries made by Walter Reed and his party.

3. This information is submitted because the Surgeon General's
Office has always been interested in the yellow fever Roll of Honor
and conferences in this office at the time had much to do with the
legislation enacted for the honor and benefit of the members of this
Roll.

C
C. R. Reynolds,
Major General, U. S. Army,
The Surgeon General.
